questions.text: You are asked to review an article titled, 'Childhood cancers- a menace'. Which of the following statements is wrong and needs to be edited out?

choices.text: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia is the most common type of leukemia in children with Down syndrome.
The most common intra-abdominal malignancy is Wilm’s tumor.
The most common extracranial solid malignancy is neuroblastoma.
The most common brain tumors in children are infratentorial.

questions.solution:
The most common intraabdominal malignancy in children is neuroblastoma. 

  • The most common leukemias seen in Down’s syndrome: acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) > acute myeloid leukemia (AML)
  • The most common site of a brain tumor in children: Infratentorium
  • The most common extra-cranial solid neoplasm in children: Neuroblastoma
  • The most common intra-abdominal neoplasm in children: Neuroblastoma
  • The most common primary neoplasm of renal tissue in children: Wilm’s tumor

questions.text: As an intern posted in paediatrics, you are asked to interpret the results of a heel prick test that you performed on a newborn. Which of the following results is suggestive of primary hypothyroidism?

choices.text: Low T4 level and low TSH level
Low T4 level and high TSH level
High T4 level and low TSH level
High T4 level and high TSH level

questions.solution:
Low T4 and high TSH levels indicate primary hypothyroidism.

Blood specimen for neonatal thyroid screening is obtained by heel prick between 1 and 5 days of life.

Levothyroxine therapy is started immediately after diagnosis, at 10 to 15 µg/kg per day.

Condition Goitre T4 TSH
Thyroid dysgenesis Absent Low Elevated
Thyroid dyshormonogenesis Present Low Elevated
Thyroid receptor blocking antibodies Absent Low Elevated
Central hypothyroidism Absent Low Normal/Low
Hyperthyroidism Present High Low

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with chronic malnutrition presents with diarrheal episodes lasting for more than 2 weeks. The stool sample is positive for Aeromonas and entero-adherent Escherichia coli.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Persistent diarrhoea(Chronic diarrhoea) is defined as a diarrhoeal episode that lasts for more than 14 days.

Diarrhoea is defined as

  • stool volume of more than 10 g/kg/day in toddlers/infants (or)
  • stool volume greater than 200 g/day in older children

Persistent diarrhoea is increasingly observed in children with malnutrition. These are due to infections commonly caused due to enteroadherent Escherichia coli and Aeromonas.

Acute diarrhoeas generally last less than 7 days while chronic diarrhoea lasts more than 14 days and is usually a non-infectious pathology.

questions.text: The expanded new Ballard score is used to assess ________
questions.solution:
The expanded new Ballard score is used to assess physical and neuromuscular maturity of the newborn.

  • There are six criteria each to assess physical maturity and neuromuscular maturity.
  • The physical maturity and neurologic maturity scores are added to calculate the gestational age.
  • It can be used to calculate gestational age from 20 to 44 weeks.
  • The Ballard scoring is accurate to +/- 2 weeks.

questions.text: Suyash, a 10-year-old boy presented to the clinic with a history of malabsorption, diarrhoea, and poor appetite after having his favourite white sauce pasta. His mother adds that he develops such symptoms only when he takes pasta or roti. The duodenal biopsy revealed crypt hyperplasia and CD8+ cells in lamina propria. Which of the following tests is least likely to be used for the diagnosis of the condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of celiac disease and an anti-nuclear antibody test is not used in the diagnosis of celiac disease.

Symptoms are pre-dominantly seen after consuming a diet rich in gluten (Wheat pasta or roti). Diagnosis of celiac disease is made based on lab and histopathological findings. 

Celiac disease-specific antibodies are as follows:

  • Anti-tissue transglutaminase (Anti-TG2) IgA antibodies
  • Anti deaminated - IgG forms of gliadin peptides antibodies
  • Endomysial antibodies (EMA)

The duodenal biopsy will show crypt hyperplasia, villous atrophy and CD8+ cells in lamina propria

questions.text: A 20-year-old primigravida was rushed to the OT for an emergency caesarean section. Her pregnancy was unplanned and she did not take folic acid supplementation prior to conception. Moreover, owing to the pandemic led lockdown and her remote residence, she could not adhere to regular antenatal care. The newborn was born with a neural tube defect and immediately shifted to the NICU. What is the least likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Holoprosencephaly is not a neural tube defect (NTD) and hence, it is the least likely diagnosis. Folic acid deficiency, especially in a young primigravida, is a risk factor for the development of NTDs in children, as seen in the given clinical vignette.

NTDs result from the failure of the neural tube to close spontaneously between the 3rd and 4th week of in utero development. These can be detected in antenatal ultrasound scans and subsequently managed for a better prognosis. The major NTDs include the following:

  • Spina bifida occulta
  • Meningocele
  • Myelomeningocele
  • Encephalocele
  • Anencephaly
  • Syringomyelia
  • Diastematomyelia (split spinal cord)
  • Iniencephaly

In holoprosencephaly, the forebrain fails to develop into two hemispheres due to mutations in the sonic hedgehog gene at the long arm of chromosome 7. It is a developmental disorder of the brain that results from the defective formation of the prosencephalon and the inadequate induction of the forebrain structures. The three types include, alobar, semilobar, and lobar, apart from the middle interhemispheric fusion variant or syntelencephaly.

The image given below shows alobar holoprosencephaly-

questions.text: An erythropoietin-secreting brain tumor is detected in a child. His father passed away one year back from end-stage renal cell carcinoma. Family history is significant for VHL mutation. On examination, a fiery red retina is seen. Which of the following is the most likely tumor present in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a cerebellar hemangioblastoma.

Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition. The major neurological features of VHL include cerebellar hemangioblastomas and retinal angiomas.

Cerebellar hemangioblastomas are erythropoietin-secreting tumors, which can lead to polycythemia. It typically appears as a cystic cerebellar lesion with a vascular mural nodule on CT or MRI scan.

Retinal angiomas are small masses of thin-walled capillaries, usually located in the peripheral retina that is fed by large and tortuous arterioles and venules appearing as a fiery red vascular mass. It can lead to retinal detachment and visual loss.

Associations of VHL syndrome include:

  • Cystic lesions of kidneys, pancreas, liver, and epididymis
  • Renal cell carcinoma (most common cause of death)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Cerebellar hemangioblastoma
  • Retinal angioma

World Brain Tumour Day is observed annually on June 8 to raise awareness among the public regarding brain tumours, and the importance of early diagnosis and treatment. The campaign also stresses the importance of more research on brain tumours to enhance the treatment methods.

Related Pearl: Malignancies Associated With Paraneoplastic Polycythemia

  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Hepatoma
  • Cerebellar hemangioma
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Pheochromocytomas
  • Virilizing ovarian tumors
  • Wilms’ tumor

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby presented with fever, poor feeding, and frequent vomiting. On examination, the head circumference was 46.5cm with a positive sunset and Macewen sign. Which of the following infections is associated with the most common cause of the underlying neurological disease in this child?
questions.solution:
Symptoms of poor feeding and frequent vomiting with signs of enlarged head circumference and a positive sunset and Macewen sign(crack-pot resonance) points toward a diagnosis of hydrocephalus. Aqueductal stenosis is the most common cause of hydrocephalus. Out of the above options, mumps infection can cause stenosis of the cerebral aqueduct. 

Mumps is associated in a child with aqueductal stenosis because-

  • Mumps virus is neurotropic and is thought to enter the CNS via the choroid plexus and infect the choroidal epithelium and ependymal cells.
  • CNS complications of mumps include meningitis, meningoencephalitis (most commonly manifests 5 days after the parotitis), transverse myelitis, aqueductal stenosis, and facial palsy.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is rushed to the casualty due to difficulty in breathing and swelling of the face and neck. Clinically, he has features suggestive of superior vena cava obstruction. Chest X-ray image shows superior mediastinal widening. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL) is the most likely diagnosis since the chest X-ray shows superior mediastinal widening- indicating an involvement of the thymus gland.

T-ALL accounts for about 15% of childhood ALL cases; it is more common in adolescents - this is the time when the thymus reaches maximum size.

60% of patients with T-ALL present with a mediastinal mass. The mediastinal mass may be asymptomatic and detected only on chest x-ray or may cause cough and dyspnea, particularly on lying flat or with facial swelling and plethora due to vascular compression (superior vena cava syndrome).

B-ALL presents usually between 1-10 years of age perhaps because the number of normal bone marrow pre-B-cells (the cell of origin) is greatest very early in life.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs potentially result in pyloric stenosis in infants?
questions.solution:
Pyloric stenosis is a potential adverse effect of erythromycin administration to an infant.

Related Pearl: Potential adverse reactions to drugs administered in infants

Drug Side effect
Oxygen Retinopathy of prematurity, bronchopulmonary dysplasia
Chloramphenicol Gray baby syndrome, bone marrow suppression
Vitamin K analogs Jaundice
Tetracycline Enamel hypoplasia
Sodium bicarbonate Intraventricular hemorrhage
Amphotericin Anuric renal failure
Indomethacin Oliguria, hyponatremia, intestinal perforation
Aminoglycosides Deafness, renal toxicity
Erythromycin Pyloric stenosis
Morphine Hypotension, urine retention

questions.text: A child is brought to the pediatrician for vaccination. The child is able to speak in	2-3 word sentences and is able to make a tower of 6 cubes. What is the expected weight of the child, if his development is normal and birth weight was 3 Kgs?
questions.solution:
The child is able to make a tower of 6 cubes and speaks in 2-3 word sentences which indicates the child is of 2 years of age. Birth weight quadruples by the age of 2 years. Hence the child's weight should be 3 kgs x 4= 12 Kgs.

Infants may lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the 1st week of life and regain it by their 2nd week.

Related Pearl: Weight and height changes in children

Term newborns may lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the first few days of life (due to extracellular fluid losses). Most healthy newborns typically regain their birth weight by 10 to 14 days. Thereafter, approximate daily weight gain is as follows :

  • 0-3 months ~ 30 grams/day
  • 3-6 months ~ 20 grams/day
  • 6-12months ~ 12-15 grams/day

Note : Infant weight approximately Doubles at 4-5 months , Triples by 1year and is 4 times by 2 years of age.

Weight gained with respect to birth weight

Age Weight
5 months 2 × birth weight
1 year 3 × birth weight
2 years 4 × birth weight
3 years 5 × birth weight

Formulae for calculating the weight in children

Age Formula
3-12 months
Weight =[age (months) + 9]
2
1-6 years Weight = [2×age (years)] + 8
7-12 years
Weight = [7×age (years) - 5]
2

Height with respect to age

Age Height
At birth 50 cm
6 months 65 cm
1 year 75 cm
2 years 90 cm
4 years 100 cm

 

Related Pearl: Important developmental milestones at various ages

Developmental milestones 

At 1 year

  • Motor: Walks with support
  • Adaptive: Mature pincer grasp
  • Language: Speaks a few words
  • Social: Plays simple ball game
  • Domestic mimicry at 18 months

At 2 years

  • Motor: Walks up and downstairs, one step at a time
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 6 blocks 
  • Language: Simple sentences, a vocabulary of 50-100 words, uses pronouns at 2.5 yrs
  • Social: Asks for food and starts toilet training, listens to stories

At 3 years

  • Motor: Rides tricycle
  • Adaptive: Makes a tower of 9 blocks, handedness is established
  • Language: Knows full name, age, gender
  • Social: Plays simple games and engages in parallel play with other children

At 4 years

  • Motor: Hops
  • Adaptive: Draws square and constructs a bridge with blocks
  • Language: Tells stories
  • Social: Goes to the toilet alone
 At 5 years
  • Motor: Skips
  • Adaptive: Draws a triangle
  • Language: Asks the meaning of words, names 4 colors
  • Social: Dresses and undresses

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric OPD with complaints of persistent fever for the past 1 week. His CBC is given below:

Hemoglobin: 5.1 g/dL

Leukocyte count: 1,40,000 cells/mm3 

Platelet count: 12,000 cells/mm3

A review of peripheral smear confirms acute myeloid leukemia. Which of the following cytogenetic findings would indicate a poor prognosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Monosomy 7 is associated with a poor prognosis in patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

The production of symptoms and signs of AML is a result of the replacement of bone marrow by malignant cells and caused by secondary bone marrow failure-pallor, fatigue, exercise intolerance, bruising, oral mucosal bleeding, or epistaxis, as well as fever, which may be caused by infection or the disease.

In addition, patients with AML present with signs and symptoms that are uncommon in Acute lymphoblastic leukemia, including subcutaneous nodules or“blueberry muffin” lesions (especially in infants), infiltration of the gingiva (especially in monocytic subtypes), signs and laboratory findings of disseminated intravascular coagulation (especially indicative of acute promyelocytic leukemia), and discrete masses, known as chloromas or granulocytic sarcomas.

Prognostic implications of chromosomal abnormalities in AML are given below:

Favorable prognosis
  • t(8;21); RUNX1-RUNX1T1
  • Inv(16) or t(16;16); CBFβ
  • NPM1 mutation
  • CEBPA mutation

Poor prognosis
  • inv(3) 
  • t(6;9)
  • 5q-
  • del(7q)
  • complex karyotype (≥3 abnormalities)
  • Monosomy7

Related Pearl: Prognostic Factors in Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

Good prognosis  Poor prognosis  
Age <40 years  Age <2 years or >55 years 
M2,M3,M4 forms of AML   M0, M6, M7 forms of AML 
TLC < 25 × 109/L  TLC > 100 × 109/L 
Blast cell with Auer rods  Deletions 5q, 7q, 20q 

t(8;21); RUNX1/ ETO fusion gene 

t(15;17); PML/ RARA fusion gene 

t(16;16) or inv 16; CBF1/ MYH1 fusion gene 

t(11q23;v) with diverse MLL fusion genes 

t(6;9)

Inversion 3
Rapid response to therapy  Delayed response to therapy 
Leukemia without preceding MDS  AML with preceding MDS or anticancer drug exposure 
Normal karyotyping with mutated NPM Complex karyotypes 
Biallelic mutation in CEBPA Activating mutation in FLT3

TLC: Total leukocyte count

MDS: Myelodysplastic syndrome

questions.text: A male infant with a weak urinary stream has the VCUG picture as shown below. All statements about this condition is true EXCEPT:

choices.text: There is a palpably distended bladder and the urinary stream is weak
A Foley (balloon) catheter should not be used
Favorable prognostic factor is a serum creatinine level >1.0 mg/dL after bladder decompression

questions.solution:
• The Voiding cystourethrogram in this infant shows posterior urethral valves. Note the dilation of the prostatic urethra and the transverse linear filling defect corresponding to the valves.
  • A serum creatinine level >1.0 mg/dL after bladder decompression in posterior urethral valves is an unfavorable prognostic factor ( NOT favorable factor).
  • A serum creatinine level <0.8-1.0 mg/dL after bladder decompression is considered favorable.

Other options: are all true

  • In the male neonate, posterior urethral valves are suspected when there is a palpably distended bladder and the urinary stream is weak.
  • A Foley (balloon) catheter should not be used, because the balloon can cause severe bladder spasm, which can produce severe ureteral obstruction.
  • 15% of boys with posterior urethral valves have unilateral reflux into a nonfunctioning dysplastic kidney, termed the VURD syndrome (valves, unilateral reflux, dysplasia).

questions.text: A woman has a previous child with congenital adrenal hyperplasia. In the present pregnancy, steroid therapy should be started _______

choices.text: As soon as pregnancy is diagnosed
After karyotyping and determination of sex of the baby

questions.solution:
Mothers with pregnancies at risk (previously affected child) of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) should be started with steroid therapy as soon as pregnancy is diagnosed.

Dexamethasone 20 μg/kg is started to suppress the secretion of steroids by the fetal adrenals (including adrenal androgens) and prevent the virilization of the external genitals in affected females.

Then, chorionic villus biopsy is performed to determine the sex and genotype of the fetus and therapy is continued only if the fetus is an affected female.

 

The drug used for prenatal therapy in CAH is dexamethasone, which is avoided if the fetus is known to be male or an unaffected female.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for NAFLD in children?
questions.solution:
Male gender is a risk factor for NAFLD (not female gender).

Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is part of the spectrum of liver disease strongly associated with obesity. It is the most common chronic liver disease in children.

NAFLD can range from fatty liver alone to a triad of fatty infiltration, inflammation, and fibrosis, termed nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).

There are 2 histologic types of NASH in children.

  • Type 1 NASH : steatosis and balloon degeneration of hepatocytes and/or periportal fibrosis.( resembles adult findings)
  • Type 2 NASH : steatosis and portal inflammation.

Risk factors for NAFLD include:

  • Obesity (38% obese children have NAFLD)
  • Male gender (not female)
  • White ethnicity
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Insulin resistance

questions.text: It is expected to see all of the following clinical features in a 5-year-old boy with nephrotic syndrome except-
questions.solution:
Hematuria is not a usual feature of nephrotic syndrome. It is a feature of nephritic syndrome. However, occasionally it is seen in the FSGS variant of nephrotic syndrome as well.

Classic features of nephrotic syndrome:

  • Nephrotic range proteinuria ( >40mg/m2/hr urine protein: creatinine ratio >2) 
  • Hypoalbuminemia (<2.5 g/dL)
  • Edema
  • Hyperlipidemia (cholesterol > 200 mg/dL)
  • Hypercoagulability

questions.text: What is the most common leukemia you would encounter in a child with the following findings?
questions.solution:
The image shows a typical Down's facies (flattened nose, flat occiput, low set ears, protruding tongue). The most common leukemia in children with Down syndrome is acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).

Children with Down syndrome are at increased risk of both acute lymphoid leukemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

10% of neonates with Down's syndrome develop transient leukemia or myeloproliferative disorder. These features usually resolve within the first 3 months of life. However, they require close follow-up, because 20–30% will develop typical leukemia (often acute megakaryocytic leukemia) by 3 years of life.

Note:

  • Most common leukemia in Down's syndrome: B-cell Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (overall)
  • The most common leukemia in children <3years of age with Down syndrome is acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
  • Most common AML in Down's syndrome: M7/megakaryoblastic

questions.text: A child is brought to the OPD for regular follow-up. Which of the following anthropometric record would prompt you to suspect a diagnosis of moderate malnutrition?

choices.text: Weight for height < -2 SD to > -3 SD
Weight for height +2 SD to +3 SD

questions.solution:
An anthropometric score of Weight for height < -2 to > -3 SD indicates moderate malnutrition.

The indicators of undernutrition include:

BMI-for-age >3 SD
Overweight

Weight-for-height/length >2 SD and ≤3 SD

BMI-for-age >2 SD and ≤3 SD
Moderately underweight Weight-for-age <–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely underweight Weight-for-age <–3 SD
Moderate acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

BMI-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference ≥115 mm and <125 mm
Severe acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length <– 3 SD

BMI-for-age <– 3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference <115 mm

Bilateral pitting edema
Moderately stunted (or) moderate chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely stunted (or) severe chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age <–3 SD

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of hypercoagulability in nephrotic syndrome?

choices.text: Vascular stasis due to hemoconcentration and intravascular volume depletion
Increase in hepatic production of fibrinogen
Urinary loss of antithrombin III and protein S

questions.solution:
Increased (and not decreased) platelet number and aggregability cause hypercoagulability in nephrotic syndrome.

Hypercoagulability in nephrotic syndrome is due to all of the following factors:

  • Vascular stasis due to hemoconcentration and intravascular volume depletion
  • Increase in hepatic production of fibrinogen
  • Urinary loss of antithrombin III and protein S
  • Increased platelet number and aggregability

questions.text: The X-ray image of a child with muscle weakness and failure to thrive is attached below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with the above X-ray image shows fraying and cupping of the metaphysis, suggestive of rickets.

Radiological features in rickets:

  • Fraying (Widening and irregularity of the growth plate)
  • Cupping (Concavity of the metaphysis)
  • Splaying at metaphysis (widening of metaphyseal ends)
  • Generalized rarefaction

Related Pearl: Radiological Features of Rickets

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Loss of provisional zone of calcification: earliest radiological finding of rickets. 
  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser. 

The above features are prominent at the growth plates where growth is greatest:

  • Knee: distal femur, proximal tibia
  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

The below image shows bowing of legs in rickets.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presented to the clinic with an acute respiratory tract infection. He has a history of asthma associated with recurrent respiratory tract infections and sinusitis. Genetic testing in childhood had revealed CFTR mutations. Which of the following is likely to be decreased in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cystic fibrosis. In these patients, sperm count is most likely to be decreased.

Male patients with cystic fibrosis usually have infertility due to failure of development of Wolffian duct structures leading to congenital absence of bilateral vas deferens. There is defective sperm transport resulting in obstructive azoospermia.

The sexual function is generally unimpaired.

Option A: Sweat chloride levels are elevated (≥60 mEq/L) due to abnormalities in the CFTR protein leading to defective chloride transport. 

Option B: Serum bicarbonate levels are increased due to excessive loss of salt in the sweat resulting in hypochloremic alkalosis.

Option D: Patients with cystic fibrosis have fat malabsorption secondary to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, hence the increased stool fat.

questions.text: A lady, with a history of a thyroid disorder and three prior abortions, delivered a female neonate prematurely at 34 weeks of gestation. In the newborn infant, tachycardia, irritability, and prominent eyes were noted and neonatal hyperthyroidism was suspected.  Which of the following statements is false about the condition?

choices.text: Maternal Graves' disease is the most common cause of neonatal hyperthyroidism
It results from the transplacental passage of maternal stimulatory TSH receptor antibody
Microcephaly and frontal bossing with triangular facies are common clinical findings
Neonatal hyperthyroidism occurs in most infants born to mothers with a history of Graves’ disease

questions.solution:
Neonatal hyperthyroidism occurs in only about 2% of infants born to mothers with a history of Graves’ disease. But maternal Graves' disease is by far the most common cause of neonatal hyperthyroidism.

Neonatal hyperthyroidism (due to Grave's) results from the transplacental passage of maternal stimulatory thyrotropin/TSH receptor antibody (TSHR-Ab).

Clinical features are as follows:

  • Low birth weight (IUGR)
  • Premature birth
  • Microcephaly
  • Frontal bossing and triangular facies
  • Warm, moist skin
  • Irritability, hyperactivity, restlessness, poor sleep
  • Tachycardia

Note:

TSHR-Ab (TSH-R-stimulating antibodies) is another name for TSH-R-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI).

questions.text: An 11-year-old child was brought to the hospital by his mother with complaints of multiple episodes of passing blood in the urine. Which of the following condition is not associated with this symptom?
questions.solution:
Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) presents with acute-onset microscopic hematuria not recurrent gross hematuria.

Causes of recurrent gross hematuria:

  • Alport’s syndrome: hereditary nephritis
  • Thin glomerular basement membrane disease
  • IgA nephropathy: Berger’s disease 
  • Idiopathic hypercalciuria/hyperuricosuria
  • Sickle cell nephropathy (papillary necrosis)

questions.text: Which of the following is a major criterion in the revised Jones criteria used for the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever in high-risk populations?
questions.solution:
Polyarthralgia is a major criterion in the revised Jones criteria used for the diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever in high-risk populations (ARF incidence >2 per 100 000 school-aged children or all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of >1 per 1000 population per year).

Strict adherence to the Jones criteria in areas of higher prevalence may result in under-diagnosis. Therefore, the criteria are slightly modified for moderate to high-risk populations as follows:

  • The major criterion of arthritis includes polyarthralgia or monoarthritis in addition to polyarthritis. Polyarthralgia should only be considered as a major manifestation after the exclusion of other causes.
  • The minor criterion for joint involvement is monoarthralgia.
  • A lower cutoff for fever is used (≥38°C [100.4°F] rather than ≥38.5°C [101.3°F]).
  • A lower cutoff for erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is used (≥30 mm/hour rather than ≥60 mm/hour), although the C-reactive protein (CRP) cutoff is unchanged (≥3 mg/dL).

Related Pearl: Revised Jones criteria for diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF)

Revised Jones criteria for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever are as follows:

Major criteria
Low-risk populations* Moderate- and high-risk populations*
   
Carditis- Clinical or subclinical Carditis- Clinical or subclinical
Arthritis- Polyarthritis only Arthritis- Polyarthritis/polyarthralgia/monoarthritis
Chorea Chorea
Erythema marginatum Erythema marginatum
Subcutaneous nodules Subcutaneous nodules
   
Minor criteria 
Polyarthralgia Monoarthralgia
Fever (≥38.5°C) Fever (≥38°C)
ESR ≥60 mm in the first hour and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL ESR ≥30 mm/hr and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL
Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) 
   
For all patient populations with evidence of preceding Group A Streptococcal infection:(Increased ASLO/ anti-DNAse B titer or positive throat culture for group A streptococcus or positive rapid streptococcal carbohydrate antigen test) 
Diagnosis of initial ARF 2 Major criteria or 1 major plus 2 minor criteria
Diagnosis of recurrent ARF 2 Major or 1 major and 2 minor or 3 minor criteria

*Low-risk populations are those with ARF incidence ≤2 per 100 000 school-aged children or all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of ≤1 per 1000 population per year. If the incidence exceeds the given limit, then it is moderate-high risk populations.

questions.text: You are posted as an intern in the pediatrics OPD and your professor asks you to examine an interesting case of cyanosis. On examination, you notice the bluish discoloration of the lower limbs but the upper limb and head are pink and on examination of the chest you see a parasternal heave and a thrill is palpable. These findings can occur in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Differential cyanosis can be seen in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) when there is a reversal of shunt.

Differential cyanosis is manifested as cyanosis of only the lower extremities while upper extremities are unaffected. It is a result of reduced arterial oxygen saturation in the distal aorta compared to that in the aorta proximal to the left subclavian artery.

 It is seen with:

  • right-to-left shunting across a ductus arteriosus in the presence of coarctation or an interrupted aortic arch
  • patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) with severe pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH)

The rest of the options cause cyanosis of all extremities. Among the options, PDA is the only condition that can manifest with differential cyanosis when there is a reversal of shunt.

Image: Right to left shunting of blood flow through a PDA between the aortic arch and pulmonary artery.

questions.text: A male infant was born to a mother with chronic hepatitis B infection. The infant is suspected to have been exposed at the time of delivery. At 4 months, which of the following viral markers signifies ongoing viral replication in the infant?
questions.solution:
HBeAg signifies the ongoing viral replication in case of hepatitis B infection.

questions.text: A junior radiologist performing a fetal doppler follows the direction of the flow of oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus to examine the fetal circulatory vessels. The sequence that he would follow is:

choices.text: Umbilical artery → inferior vena cava → ductus venosus → right atrium → left atrium
Umbilical artery → superior vena cava → right atrium → ductus arteriosus → left atrium
Umbilical vein → ductus venosus → inferior vena cava → right atrium → left atrium
Umbilical vein → ductus arteriosus → superior vena cava → right atrium → left atrium

questions.solution:
The sequence of oxygenated blood flow from the placenta to the fetal heart is umbilical vein → ductus venosus → inferior venacava → right atrium → left atrium.

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

questions.text: Following a delivery complicated by shoulder dystocia, the baby is noted to have a deformity in the right upper limb. On inspection, the orthopedics JR notes an adducted, internally rotated arm and a pronated forearm. Which nerve roots are affected here?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of Erb–Duchenne paralysis. The injury is limited to the 5th and 6th cervical nerve roots.

The characteristic position consists of adduction and internal rotation of the arm with pronation of the forearm. There is loss of abduction of the shoulder, external rotation, and supination.

There is an asymmetric Moro's Reflex

Note:
In shoulder dystocia, the most common nerve injury is to the C5-6 nerve root. The most common bone to fracture is the clavicle.

questions.text: A pediatrician suspects vesicoureteric reflux in a girl with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. What is the investigation of choice to confirm this condition?
questions.solution:
Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) is the investigation of choice for vesicoureteral reflux.

Recurrent febrile urinary tract infections in a child should raise the suspicion of an anatomical defect like vesicoureteric reflux as the cause. Compared to other investigations, a VCUG provides more anatomic information. It can demonstrate:

  • Vesicoureteral reflux
  • Duplex collecting system
  • Ectopic ureter
  • Paraureteral (bladder) diverticulum
  • Bladder outlet obstruction
  • Signs of voiding dysfunction, such as a spinning top urethra

questions.text: Maternal intake of statins causes ______ in fetus:
questions.solution:
• Maternal intake of Statins can adversely affect the fetus by causing
    • IUGR
    • Limb deficiencies
    • VACTERAL (vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb) defect.
  • Other options:

Maternal drug intake – adverse effect on fetus:

  • Penicillamine  - Cutis laxa syndrome
  • Lithium - Ebstein anomaly, macrosomia
  • Accutane (isotretinoin) -  Facial-ear anomalies, heart disease, CNS anomalies

questions.text: Deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase causes _____________
questions.solution:
Deficiency of the enzyme porphobilinogen deaminase causes acute intermittent porphyria.

Other options:

  • Porphyria cutanea tarda: Deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase (UROD)
  • Variegate porphyria: Deficiency of Protoporphyrinogen oxidase (PPOX)
  •  X-Linked protoporphyria: Gain of function mutation of δ-aminolevulinate synthase 2 (ALAS2)

questions.text: Substitution of lysine for glutamic acid residue in the 6th position of the beta-globin gene leads to formation of__________
questions.solution:
• HbC is due to substitution of Lysine for Glutamic acid residue in the 6th position of the beta-globin gene.
  • HbS is due to substitution of Valine for Glutamic acid in the 6th position of the beta-globin gene.
  • Hb Bart is the deletion of all four alpha globin genes. (There are only 2 beta globin genes)
  • HbH is the deletion of three alpha globin genes.

questions.text: On suddenly dropping an infant’s head in relation to her trunk, you notice the response seen in the image. Which of the following is incorrect regarding different components of this response?

choices.text: Hand opening is present by 28 weeks
Upper limb extension and abduction is present by 32 weeks
Anterior flexion with audible cry appears by 40 weeks

questions.solution:
The given image demonstrates Moro’s Reflex. In Moro's reflex, anterior flexion with audible cry appears at 37 weeks.

 The different components of Moro's reflex appear as following:

  • Hand opening appears at 28 weeks.
  • Upper Limb extension and abduction appear at 32 weeks.
  • Anterior flexion with audible cry appears at 37 weeks

Moro’s reflex disappears by 5-6 months of age.

An asymmetrical Moro's reflex is indicative of root plexus injury.

Moro’s is considered to be the only unlearned fear in human newborns.

According to Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 9th edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 4 months of age. According to Nelson Paediatrics, 21st edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 6 months of age. Hence, the answer depends on the reference chosen by the examiner.

questions.text: Marked accumulation of cholesterol and lipids in the adrenal cortex and gonads associated with severe impairment of all steroidogenesis is seen in
questions.solution:
• Lipoid adrenal hyperplasia is usually caused by mutations in the gene for steroidogenic acute regulatory protein (StAR), a mitochondrial protein.
  • Patients with this disorder exhibit marked accumulation of cholesterol and lipids in the adrenal cortex and gonads, associated with severe impairment of ALL steroidogenesis.

questions.text: According to current recommended dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be __________ of total energy intake.
questions.solution:
According to current dietary guidelines for children, energy from saturated fats should be <10% of total energy intake. Diets that are low in saturated fat and cholesterol (<300mg/day) without transfat are preferred. 

Acceptable macronutrient distribution ranges (AMDA % of energy) are given below: 

Macronutrient Age 1 to 3 years Age 4 to 18 years
Fats 30 to 40 25 to 35
Protein 5 to 20 10 to 30
Carbohydrate 45 to 65 45 to 65

questions.text: Which of the following intrauterine infections is associated with limb reduction defects and scarring of skin?
questions.solution:
• Intrauterine infections associated with limb reduction defects and scarring of skin are associated with fetal varicella syndrome.

  • Fetal varicella infection occurs if maternal infection occurs during first half of pregnancy.
  • Its features include cicatrising skin lesions, micropthalmia, cataracts, optic atrophy, chorioretinitis, microcephaly, limb hypoplasia along with motor and sensory deficits.

questions.text: A boy who attends school is sent to the principal's office as he often distracts others by rhythmically rocking back and forth on his seat. His mother worried about his behavior brings him to you. She also gives you a history of seizures. On examination, you notice he has blonde hair, fair skin, microcephaly, prominent maxillae with widely spaced teeth, and growth retardation. His urine changes its color transiently to blue-green on the addition of 1ml ferric chloride solution. What is the cause of CNS symptoms in this child?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of phenylketonuria. CNS damage in patients with phenylketonuria (PKU) is caused by hyperphenylalaninemia in brain tissue.

High blood levels of phenylalanine saturate the transport system across the blood-brain barrier causing inhibition of the cerebral uptake of other large neutral amino acids such as tyrosine and tryptophan impairing brain protein synthesis. 

Microcephaly, prominent maxillae with widely spaced teeth, enamel hypoplasia, and growth retardation are other common findings in untreated children. Low bone mineral density and osteopenia have been reported in affected individuals of all ages.

Excess phenylalanine is metabolized to phenyl ketones (phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate) that are excreted in the urine. However, these metabolites have no role in the pathogenesis of CNS damage; their presence in body fluids simply signifies the severity of the condition.

Hypotyrosinemia can be partially responsible for the signs and symptoms but the primary cause is hyperphenylalaninemia.

Laboratory diagnoses of phenylketonuria include:

  • Guthrie's test: growth of bacillus subtilis is seen
  • Ferric chloride urine test: transient blue-green color 
  • Blood phenylalanine levels: elevated
  • Enzyme studies
  • Genetic mutation studies
  • Tandem mass spectrometry: Gold standard screening method for all metabolic disorders.

questions.text: This histopathological image of a 3 year old shows the presence of a mural nodule in posterior cranial fossa. Which tumor does this finding indicate?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows the presence of a large cystic mass with an enhancing mural nodule in the cerebellum. Along with the age of the patient being 3 years indicates pilocytic astrocytoma.
  • Pilocytic astrocytoma (PA) is a low grade astrocytoma and is the most common type of astrocytoma in children. Its classic site of occurrence is the cerebellum but can occur in other parts of the CNS.
  • Another feature that helps in its diagnosis is the presence of Rosenthal fibres which are condensed masses of glial fragments.
  • PAs generally do not undergo malignant change and are rarely invasive.
  • Primary approach to treatment is surgical resection along with chemotherapy and radiation.
  • Other posterior cranial fossa tumors seen in children are given in the following table:

questions.text: True about breath holding spell is

choices.text: Occurs between 1 to 6 months of age

questions.solution:
Breath holding spells are typically initiated by a provocative event that causes anger, frustration causing child to cry.

  • Tonic – clonic seizures may occur if it lasts for more than aa few seconds
  • Recovery within seconds is followed by normal activity
  • Occur between 6 months to 5 years of age
  • Peaks at 2 years
  • Treatment – Reassurance

questions.text: Who among  the following children with Kawasaki’s disease is at greatest risk for coronary aneurysms?

choices.text: 8 year-old girl with 6 days of high fever and strawberry tongue
5-year-old boy with 8 days of fever and CSF pleocytosis
2-year-old girl with IVIG treatment at 7th day of fever
11-year-old boy with 15 days of fever and low PCV

questions.solution:
An 11-year-old boy with 15 days of fever and low PCV is at the greatest risk for coronary aneurysms.

Risk factors for coronary aneurysms in Kawasaki's disease:

  • Age younger than 1 year or older than 9 years
  • Male sex
  • Fever ≥14 days
  • Hematocrit(PCV) <35 percent 
  • Serum sodium concentration <135 mEq/L
  • White blood cell count >12,000/mm3
  • Elevated ESR and CRP

Administration of IVIG during the first 10 days of illness reduces the prevalence of coronary aneurysms fivefold.

questions.text: A mother observed deterioration in her young child's academic performance and loss of interest in everyday activities for the last few weeks. She has also lost the ability to play catch with her brother and complains of muscle weakness. There is mild hepatomegaly noted on examination. Her serum ceruloplasmin levels were reduced. All of the following manifestations can occur in a patient with this disease except?
questions.solution:
The presence of reduced ceruloplasmin levels, motor incoordination, and hepatomegaly suggest the patient is suffering from Wilson’s disease. Sparse depigmented hair is not a feature of Wilson's disease. It is a feature of Menke's disease.

Wilson's disease is caused due to a mutation in the ATP7B gene that leads to excess deposition of free copper within tissues.

It has the following clinical features:

System Clinical features

(most common)

Jaundice
Abdominal pain
Hepatomegaly
Fatigue

Variceal bleed
Coagulation defects
Neurological Dysarthria
Dystonia

Subcortical dementia

Wing beating tremors
Decreased scholastic performance
Ophthalmic Kayser-Fleischer (KF) rings
Sunflower cataract
Others Hemolytic anemia (Coombs negative)
Acute pancreatitis
Fanconi's syndrome
Hyperparathyroidism
Cardiomyopathy

Infertility

Note: Wilson's disease may also present as cirrhosis and hepatic failure, where shrinkage of liver occurs.

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: A toddler is brought by his mother with complaints of poor feeding, lethargy, and chronic diarrhea for the past 4 months. Upon clinical examination, the child has pale conjunctiva and is tachycardic.  Blood workup reveals low hemoglobin and smear shows macrocytosis, anisopoikilocytosis, and large neutrophils with hyper-segmented nuclei. Serum homocysteine levels are elevated and methylmalonate levels are normal. Bone marrow shows erythroid hyperplasia. Which of the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: Lactate dehydrogenase levels in serum is low.
Folate-deficient mother's give birth to infants with folate deficiency.
Methylenetetrahydrofolate (MTHFR) deficiency is associated with megaloblastic anemia.
Goat’s milk fed infants are more likely to develop this disease

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the megaloblastic picture elevated homocysteine levels, and normal methylmalonate levels are suggestive of folate deficiency anemia. 

Goat’s milk is deficient in folate. So goat milk-fed infants are likely to develop folate deficiency anemia. Human breast milk, infant formulas, and pasteurized cow’s milk provide adequate amounts of folic acid.

In folate deficiency anemia, lactate dehydrogenase levels in serum are elevated. Folate-deficient mothers do not give birth to infants with folate deficiency because there is a selective transfer of folate to the fetus via the placental folate receptors.

Methylenetetrahydrofolate (MTHFR) deficiency is the most common inborn error of folate metabolism, and severe cases can produce neurologic and vascular complications; there is no associated megaloblastic anemia.

Malnutrition is the most common cause of folate deficiency in children.

Note: Both homocysteine and methylmalonate levels are elevated in B12 deficiency anemia.

questions.text: On your pediatrics rotation, you notice a 2-day-old baby with the rash shown in the image below. Which among the following is the most likely cause for this baby's rash?
questions.solution:
The image shows purple papulonodular lesions, which are suggestive of blueberry muffin rash. It is seen in congenital rubella.

Blueberry muffin rash represents dermal erythropoiesis. In addition to congenital rubella, it can be seen in: 

  • Congenital viral infections such as cytomegalovirus and parvovirus
  • Neoplasms such as neuroblastoma and acute myeloid leukemia
  • Rh hemolytic disease

questions.text: A 2-month-old child is brought to your OPD with complaints of diarrhoea. The mother wants to know if she should continue breastfeeding. Which of these components in breast milk, beneficial in intestinal cell maturation and repair, prompt you to advise her to continue breastfeeding?
questions.solution:
The epidermal growth factor present in breastmilk helps in intestinal cell maturation and repair. This is why mothers are advised to continue breastfeeding in an infant affected with diarrhoea. It is also beneficial in luminal surveillance.

Lactoferrin (Option A) helps in immunomodulation, iron chelation, antimicrobial action. It is also an antiadhesive and trophic for intestinal growth. 

Para-aminobenzoic acid (Option C) is present in low levels and offers protection against plasmodium. 

Glutathione peroxidase (Option D) prevents lipid oxidation. 

World Breastfeeding Week is held annually from August 1 to 7 and is supported by WHO, UNICEF, and health ministries. The theme of this year is "Closing the gap: Breastfeeding support for all" - highlighting the importance of recognising and supporting breastfeeding mothers, sharing experiences, and promoting multi-level support through policies, building a breastfeeding-friendly healthcare system, respect for women's autonomy, and community solidarity.

questions.text: Vikas, a high school student is observed to have an indented 'en coup de sabre' lesion as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
En coup de sabre lesion is seen in juvenile localized scleroderma (morphea).

It appears as an indented, vertical, colourless, line of skin on the forehead. The indentation looks as though the person may have been struck (coup) by a sword (sabre). This lesion involves the scalp and/or face and often extend into the central nervous system, resulting in neurologic sequelae such as seizures and headaches.

questions.text: Which of the following cardiac lesions are expected in the patient seen in the image?
questions.solution:
This is a patient seen with webbed neck – In Turner’s syndrome

Turner’s syndrome:

  • Also known as Ullrisch- Turner syndrome or ‘Gonadal dysgenesis’ – Caused by absence of set of genes from the short arm of X chromosome ( 45XO )
  • In females – breast development is absent with ovarian failure and primary or secondary amenorrhea.
  • Lymphadema, short stature
  • Widely spaced nipples
  • Low set ears, low hairline and webbed neck
  • Multiple pigmented nevi
  • Horse shoe kidney
  • Cardiac manifestations – Coarctation of aorta, bicuspid aortic valve
  • Treatment – GH, Estrogen replacement therapy

questions.text: A pediatrician is evaluating a toddler for mental retardation. She hands a bright red ball to the baby and lets him play with it.  She then takes the ball and hides it under a blanket in front of him. The child confusedly stares at the blanket and cries instead of searching for it. What is being tested here?
questions.solution:
Understanding that objects continue to exist even when not seen is called object permanence. This is due to an ability to form a mental representation of the object. It is attained at the age of 8–9 months.

Option A: Separation anxiety begins at about 9 months of age. Children wake up crying from their naps as they realize that their parents are not in the same room as them. This is different from stranger anxiety displayed by the child at the age of 6-7 months, wherein they react to approaching strangers by crying or clinging to their parent.

Option B: A transitional object is an object, such as a blanket or a stuffed toy, that is used by many children as a symbol of the absent parent. It is seen at around 18 months.

Option C: Symbolic transformations in play:

  • At 12 months - make-believe (symbolic) play centres on the child’s own body, e.g., the child pretends to drink from an empty cup.
  • At 18 month - symbolic transformations in play are not limited to the child's body, e.g., a doll can be fed from a plate.

questions.text: A baby in the NICU is being evaluated for his features of microcephaly and hepatomegaly. CT scan revealed nodular periventricular calcifications. Congenital CMV infection is suspected. Which of the following samples is the best to detect the organism using PCR?
questions.solution:
Among the following options, urine is the best sample to be sent for the diagnosis of congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. 

In congenital CMV infections, the investigation of choice is PCR or viral culture. It should be done within the first three weeks of life (after this period, it is difficult to distinguish between a congenital and an acquired infection). Since not all affected infants are viremic at birth, urine is a more reliable sample than blood. 

Most CMV transmission occurs in the first trimester. The risk of transmission is high in the third trimester. 90% of the infected babies are asymptomatic and have lesser chances of having late sequelae. 

The clinical manifestations include hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. Neuroimaging shows intracranial periventricular calcifications. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss.

There is no definitive treatment for congenital CMV infection. Treatment with ganciclovir is indicated only in patients with progressive neurologic disease and deafness.

questions.text: A newborn baby at one minute of life has a heart rate 60/min, irregular respiration, with some flexion of limbs. The baby was pale and had a grimace response on passing the nasal catheter. What is the apgar score at one minute?
questions.solution:
This baby has an apgar score of 4. 

Heart rate 60/min- 1

Irregular respiration- 1

Some flexion of limbs- 1

Grimace-1

The baby was pale-0

The Apgar score is a practical method of systematically assessing newborn infants immediately after birth.

An infant with a score of 0-3 requires immediate resuscitation.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Head reaches 90% of adult size at 1 year
Lymphoid growth follows a sigmoid-shaped pattern
Perinatal period is between 28 weeks of gestation to 7 days after birth
Growth of child is cephalocaudal and distal to proximal

questions.solution:
Growth of child is cephalocaudal and distal to proximal. 

During fetal life, the growth of the head occurs before that of the neck, and arms grow before legs. The distal parts of the body such as hands increase in size before the upper arms.

Growth Development
Denotes a net increase in size/mass of tissues Denotes maturation of functions

Cephalocaudal

Head ⇒ Neck ⇒ Trunk & upper limbs ⇒ Lower limbs

Distal ⇒ Proximal

Hands increase in size before upper arms

 Proximal ⇒ Distal

Hand use is learnt before the use of fingers

Growth rate of different tissues:

  • Brain growth: At age of 1 month, the head size is about 36% of the expected head size in adults. It doubles in the first year of life to 72% and becomes 83% of adult size at 2 years.
  • Lymphoid growth: It is prominent in mid-childhood. It peaks at 4–8 years and regresses subsequently.
  • Gonadal growth: It stays dormant during childhood and shows a rise with the onset of puberty.
  • Somatic growth: General body growth shows an S-shaped curve. It is rapid during the fetal period and the first 3–4 years. It is steady in the following period, followed by a growth spurt during puberty. Later, it slows down considerably.

Note: WHO defines the perinatal period from 22 weeks of gestation (or ≥500 g) up to 7 days after birth.

  • Order of Growth: Distal ⇒ Proximal 
  • Order of Development: Proximal ⇒ Distal

Related Pearl: Periods of growth

Prenatal period
Zygote 0 to 14 days of gestation
Embryo 3 weeks to 8 weeks
Fetus 9 weeks to birth
Perinatal period 22 weeks to 7 days after birth

 

Postnatal period
Newborn (neonate) First 4 weeks after birth
Infancy The first year
Toddler 1 to 3 years
Preschool child 3 to 6 years
School-age child 6 to 12 years

 

Adolescence
Early 10 to 13 yr
Middle 14 to 16 yr
Late 17 to 19 yr

questions.text: Anika, a 6-year-old girl good at sprint events, has been avoiding her track practices over the recent few weeks. Her mother informs that she skips her classes owing to her knee pain. Her X-ray reveals subperiosteal haemorrhages. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of pseudoparalysis which is a feature of scurvy - vitamin C deficiency

The subperiosteal haemorrhages in the lower limb bones can cause acute swelling and pain; the condition might mimic acute osteomyelitis or arthritis. The child refuses to walk because of the pain; hence, it is called pseudoparalysis.

questions.text: You are reading an article titled, ' Dark age vampires or our patients', which describes an 18-year-old man who has had an intolerance to sunshine since the age of 6. When playing cricket he suffered intense burning, redness, swelling, and crusting of knees unprotected by shorts, with similar changes on cheeks and bridge of the nose. His labs showed elevated concentrations of total erythrocyte protoporphyrin. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies can explain this boy's condition?
questions.solution:
Symptoms of cutaneous photosensitivity beginning in childhood and a substantially elevated concentration of total erythrocyte protoporphyrin supports a diagnosis of erythropoietic protoporphyria. The enzyme deficient in erythropoietic protoporphyria is ferrochelatase (FECH).

Symptoms consist of acute pain and itching often occurring within minutes of sunlight exposure and followed by redness and swelling with continued exposure. Swelling may resemble angioneurotic edema and solar urticaria. Symptoms are usually worse in the spring and summer. Chronic changes may include lichenification, leathery pseudovesicles, labial grooving, and nail changes, but changes in pigmentation and pronounced scarring are unusual.

Life-threatening protoporphyric hepatopathy is characterized by greater increases in erythrocyte and plasma protoporphyrin levels, increased photosensitivity, and either chronically abnormal liver function tests or rapidly progressive hepatic failure.

Afamelanotide, a synthetic analogue of the alpha-melanocyte-stimulating hormone is recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of erythropoietic protoporphyria. The drug acts by increasing sunlight tolerance.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

(PPOX)
 Increased urinary ALA, PBG, and coproporphyrin III and fecal protoporphyrin IX Both
Photosensitivity, neurologic symptoms, developmental delay
Erythropoietic protoporphyria
(EPP)
Ferrochelatase
(FECH)
 Increased fecal and red cell protoporphyrin IX  Cutaneous photosensitivity
Non-blistering Photosensitivity with skin lesions
 
Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:
  • ALAD enzyme deficiency porphyria
  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic protoporphyria
  • X-linked protoporphyria

questions.text: Silverman anderson score is used to assess which of the following parameters?

choices.text: To assess disease severity in NICU

questions.solution:
Silverman Anderson score is used to assess severity of respiratory distress in neonates. Score >6 indicates impending respiratory failure.

Silverman Anderson Score:

Score Upper chest retraction Lower chest retraction Xiphoid retraction Nasal dilatation  Grunt
0 Synch none none none none
1 Lag on inspiration Just visible Just visible Minimal Stethoscope
2 See-saw Marked marked marked naked ear

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl, a known case of celiac disease, presented to the pediatric endocrine clinic with a history of neck swelling, tremor, and weight loss. On evaluation, she was found to have Graves’ disease. Other conditions that need to be screened in this patient include all of the following except __________.
questions.solution:
Type 2 Diabetes mellitus is not associated with Grave's disease.

Conditions associated with Grave's disease (autoimmune diseases): 

  • Diabetes mellitus type 1
  • Pernicious anaemia
  • Celiac disease
  • Vitiligo
  • Addison disease
  • Alopecia areata
  • Myasthenia gravis

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy who has been operated on for craniopharyngioma presents with polyuria and polydipsia. On investigation, the serum osmolality is 305 mOsm/kg and urine osmolality is 250 mOsm/kg.  The atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) level is normal. What could be the cause?

choices.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with ↑serum osmolality and ↓urinary osmolality, after a cranial surgery, suggests a diagnosis of post-surgical central diabetes insipidus (DI). Irreversible central DI follows most cases of complete resections of craniopharyngioma.

Serum osmolality of >295 mOsm/L (normal: 280-295 mOsm/L) and the urine osmolality of <300 mOsm/L (normal: 500-850mOsm/L) are suggestive of DI. A water deprivation test is done to further classify the types of DI.  

Option A: In postoperative patients, because of IV fluids there is an acute expansion of ECF volume. This suppresses high ADH activity and causes diuresis with normal serum osmolality.

Option B: In SIADH, serum osmolality is decreased.

Option D: In cerebral salt-wasting syndrome there is hypersecretion ANP and their levels are usually elevated.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl was brought to the OPD by her mother who is concerned about her significant increase in height compared to her classmates in the last 2 years. On examination, the girl shows breast development corresponding to B2 Tanner stage. What is the most common brain lesion causing this condition?
questions.solution:
Hypothalamic hamartoma, a neuronal migration defect, is the most common cause of organic central precocious puberty. The onset of breast development before the age of 8 years in females and onset of testicular development (>4 mL) before the age of 9 years in males is suggestive of central precocious puberty. 

It is a congenital malformation that consists of ectopically located neural tissue characterised by-

  • Early-onset of puberty
  • Seizures associated with unnatural crying or laughing episodes are known as gelastic seizures.

Tuberculous meningitis, tuberous sclerosis, and astrocytomas can also cause central precocious puberty.

questions.text: The earliest indicator of response after starting iron therapy in a 6 year old with iron deficiency is
questions.solution:
• Reticulocyte count is the earliest to rise after starting iron therapy.
  • This is followed by elevation of haemoglobin levels.
  • Body iron stores are repleted after the correction of haemoglobin levels.

questions.text: A 22 year old boy admitted to casualty with history of breathlessness following massage by mother. He had a history of hairline ankle fracture and was on a below knee cast which was removed recently. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation of immobilization after application of knee cast sets in a risk factor for Deep Vein Thrombosis. Massaging the leg may dislodge the thrombus causing pulmonary embolism.

Pulmonary embolism is the commonest complication of deep vein thrombosis leading to death.

Deep Vein Thrombosis:

Causes

  • Postoperative thrombosis: (Most common cause)
    • Following childbirth
    • Trauma- to leg, ankle, thigh, pelvis
    • Muscular violence
    • Immobility – Bed-ridden patients, individuals on long-duration air or bus travel (Traveller’s thrombosis).
    • Debilitating illness, obesity, immobility, bed rest, pregnancy, puerperium, oral contraceptives, estrogens.

Sites

  1. Pelvic veins—common
  2. Leg veins—common in femoral and popliteal veins (Common on the left side).

Features of DVT

  • Fever-commonest
  • Tense, tender, warm, pale/bluish, shiny swelling calf
  • Positive Homan’s, Mose’s or Neuhof’s signs
  • Inverted champagne bottle sign
  • Commonly it is asymptomatic
  • Features of pulmonary embolism

Treatment

  • Rest, elevation of the limb, bandaging the entire limb with
  • crepe bandage.
  • Anticoagulants: Heparin/low molecular weight
  • heparin, warfarin, phenindione.
  • Palma operation
  • May-Husni operation

questions.text:
A child with CAH having cortisol deficiency is treated with glucocorticoids. How should the dose of glucocorticoids be altered during an inter-current infection?

CAH - Congenital Adrenal hyperplasia

choices.text: Dose should be tapered and stopped
Dose should be doubled or tripled
Glucocorticoids should be withdrawn until the infection resolves

questions.solution:
Cortisol deficiency in CAH is treated with glucocorticoids.

Double or triple doses are indicated during periods of stress, such as an infection or surgery. This is because, during periods of stress, the requirement for cortisol is higher.

questions.text: LBW is associated with increased risk of _____ in adult life.
questions.solution:
Low birth weight (LBW) (< 2.5kg) is associated with an increased risk of hypertension, stroke, and type 2 diabetes in adulthood.

The risk is exacerbated by low weight gain during the first 2 years of life.

questions.text: The image given below depicts a skin manifestation of a neurocutaneous disorder. Which of the following conditions given below are not associated with this neurocutaneous disorder?
questions.solution:
The image shows the shagreen patch seen in tuberous sclerosis. Out of the given options, Lisch nodules is not associated with tuberous sclerosis. Lisch nodules are associated with neurofibromatosis.

Clinical features of tuberous sclerosis:

  • CNS involvement (hallmark of tuberous sclerosis)
    • Subependymal nodules are lesions found along the wall of the lateral ventricles where they undergo calcification
    • These benign subependymal nodules lesions can grow into subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SEGA)
    • The characteristic brain lesion is a cortical tuber (white matter lesion)
  • Skin
    • Facial angiofibroma (adenoma sebaceum)
    • Periungual fibroma
    • Shagreen patch
    • Confetti skin lesions
  • Others
    • Renal angiomyolipoma
    • Cardiac rhabdomyoma

Facial angiofibromas (Adenoma sebaceum)

Periungual fibroma:

Confetti skin lesions:

questions.text: A 5 day old infant seen with this transient rash. These papular lesions on an erythematous base on microscopic examination will reveal:
questions.solution:
The picture shown above is that of Erythema toxicum which are eosinophil laden sterile lesions.

  • They are papular lesions on an erythematous base seen in many babies
  • They are distributed over the trunk and face predominantly
  • Seen 1-3 days after birth and may persist for 1 week
  • They resolve spontaneously and do not require any treatment

Neutrophils are seen in lesions of Pustular Melanosis which is another benign transient skin finding in newborns.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly in newborns?
questions.solution:
Aqueductal stenosis is the most common cause of ventriculomegaly and hydrocephalus in newborns.

Ventriculomegaly is the dilation of the ventricles. When ventriculomegaly occurs in association with raised cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure, it is called hydrocephalus.

Pathologic etiologies can be congenital or acquired. Congenital causes include structural abnormalities such as aqueductal stenosis, agenesis of the corpus callosum, Dandy-Walker malformations, Chiari malformations, and neural tube defects. Acquired causes are intracranial infections(cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis), intracranial hemorrhage, ischemic injury, and brain parenchymal tumors.

Aqueductal stenosis is the narrowing or obstruction of the cerebral aqueduct, a narrow channel that connects the third and fourth ventricles in the brain. As a result, the fluid accumulates within the ventricles, causing them to enlarge.

Treatment for aqueductal stenosis includes ventriculostomy, diuretics, serial lumbar punctures in specific cases, and CSF diversion. In severe cases, CSF diversion procedures (shunting), may be necessary to redirect the flow of CSF and relieve pressure on the brain.

questions.text: A newborn female presents with continuous dribbling of urine. The image below shows the pathology from which the patient is suffering. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Neonate with continuous urine dribbling a protruding bladder with exposed mucosa suggests bladder exstrophy.

In bladder exstrophy, the bladder protrudes from the abdominal wall, and its mucosa is exposed. The umbilicus is displaced downwards, the pubic rami are widely separated and the rectus muscles are separated. Anomalies of the bladder occur when the mesoderm fails to invade the cephalad extension of the cloacal membrane, the extent of this failure determines the degree of the anomaly.

Males commonly have complete epispadias with dorsal chordee, undescended testes, short penis, and inguinal hernia. Epispadias with separation of the two halves of the clitoris and wide separation of labia is seen in females. Anus is displaced anteriorly in both sexes. Rectal prolapse may be seen.

Management involves a staged surgical reconstruction of the bladder and genitalia. Untreated patients may develop total urinary incontinence and an increased incidence of bladder adenocarcinoma.

Other exstrophy anomalies are cloacal exstrophy and epispadias. Cloacal exstrophy (ileocaecal exstrophy) is a rare condition, in which there is a small exomphalos with an everted caecum and ileum separating halves of the bladder and in males, a split penis. The hindgut is truncated (giving tusks on the face of the elephant appearance).  

Other options: 

Option A: Gastroschisis is a condition where the intestinal loops herniate through the defect in the abdominal wall (shown below). The defect usually lies on one side of the umbilicus (right side commonly). The loops of the bowel are not covered by amnion as they herniate through the abdominal wall directly into the amniotic cavity. It is associated with elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels. 

Option D: Mild forms of the imperforate anus are often called anal stenosis or an anterior ectopic anus.

questions.text: A cyanotic newborn is suspected of having congenital heart disease. He has an increased left ventricular impulse and a holosystolic murmur along the left sternal border. ECG shows left axis deviation and left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Clinical cyanosis in combination with left-axis deviation (LAD) and left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) noted on the electrocardiogram distinguishes tricuspid atresia from most other cyanotic heart lesions.

Other points in favor:

  • Increased left ventricular impulse (in contrast to most other causes of cyanotic heart disease, in which an increased right ventricular impulse).
  • Holosystolic murmurs audible along the left sternal border (due to associated ventricular septal defect).

Tricuspid atresia is the congenital absence of the tricuspid valve. So, blood cannot flow directly from the right atrium to the right ventricle, and the following associated defects are necessary for survival:

  • Patent foramen ovale or atrial septal defect: for the flow of blood from the right atrium to the left atrium
  • Ventricular septal defect: for the flow of blood from the left ventricle to the right ventricle
  • There is a hypoplastic right ventricle.

Option B and D: Truncus arteriosus and tetralogy of Fallot and - The ECG demonstrates right axis deviation (RAD) and evidence of RVH.

Option A: Transposition of great arteries- ECG is usually normal, showing the neonatal right-sided dominant pattern.

questions.text: Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, was observed in a neonate. On investigating, liver enzymes, PT/INR and albumin levels were normal. No hemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. A drop in bilirubin level was observed within a week after treating with phenobarbital. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Jaundice persisiting 3 weeks after birth is suggestive of pathological jaundice. Among the given options, Crigler Najjar type 2 presents with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia which responds to phenobarbital therapy.  

Dubin Johnson (option C) and Rotor (option A) syndromes lead to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. 

Crigler Najjar type 2 is an autosomal recessive disease with non-hemolytic, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia caused by homozygous missense mutations in the enzyme UDP UGT1A1 resulting in reduced (partial) enzymatic activity.

The differences between Crigler-Najjar type 1 and type 2 are described in the table below:

Crigler Najjar Type 1   Crigler Najjar Type 2
Autosomal recessive   Autosomal recessive
UDPGT is absent   UDPGT is reduced
Severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia   Less severe
Pale stools   Normal-coloured stools
May proceed to kernicterus and does not respond to phenobarbitone   Does not proceed to kernicterus and is responsive to phenobarbitone

questions.text: A final year student is asked to give a seminar on 'fetal circulation.' Which among the following statement told by him in the seminar is likely to be false?

choices.text: Heart receives blood with high oxygen saturation
Pressure in right and left ventricles are equal
Liver receives blood with low oxygen saturation compared to the brain
Blood in inferior venacava has lower oxygen concentration compared to superior venacava

questions.solution:
Blood in the inferior vena cava has a higher oxygen concentration compared to the superior vena cava.

The superior vena cava carries the deoxygenated blood from the upper part of the body to the right atrium. The highly oxygenated blood is carried to the fetus from the placenta via the umbilical vein with 50% of the umbilical venous blood entering the hepatic circulation and the rest bypassing the liver and joining the inferior vena cava (IVC) via the ductus venosus. Hence, the blood in the inferior vena cava has a higher oxygen concentration compared to the superior vena cava. Also, relatively a larger percentage of oxygen-rich blood is perfused to the brain.

Pressures in both the right and left ventricles are equal in a developing fetus. The upper part of the body is perfused exclusively by the left ventricle while the lower extremities are perfused by the right ventricle. 

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

questions.text: The parents of a neonate diagnosed with congenital adrenal hyperplasia come with queries about the disease. They have been told that it's an inherited condition and ask you how is it possible for the baby to be affected when neither of the parents are. What is the mode of inheritance of the disease?
questions.solution:
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia / adrenogenital syndrome follows an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.

Depending on the enzyme that is deficient, patients will have :

  • Mineralocorticoid deficiency (hyponatremia, hyperkalemia) or excess (hypernatremia, hypokalemia)
  • Incomplete virilization or precocious puberty in males
  • Virilization or sexual infantilism in females

questions.text: At your vaccination center, you have noticed increased reporting of vaccine-associated paralytic polio (VAPP). Which of the following statement is true regarding this adverse effect of the vaccine?

choices.text: It occurs mostly after the first dose of oral polio vaccine
It is more likely to occur if the first dose was parenteral inactivated polio vaccine
It Is most likely to occur if given on the same day as yellow fever vaccine
It is more likely to occur if multiple parenteral injections have been given at the same time

questions.solution:
Vaccine-associated paralytic polio (VAPP) occurs mostly after the first dose of oral polio vaccine (OPV).

VAPP is said to occur if:

  • Acute flaccid paralysis occurred 4 to 40 days after receiving OPV, and residual weakness lasted for more than 60 days after the onset of paralysis.
  • Isolation of vaccine-related poliovirus in any stool samples and no isolation of wild poliovirus from any stool samples.

Note:

  • VAPP: Vaccine-associated paralytic polio
  • VDPV: Vaccine-derived polio virus.  A very rare strain of polio virus, genetically changed from the original strain contained in OPV. 
  • cVDPV: circulating vaccine-derived polio virus. In areas of low vaccination coverage, a VDPV strain may revert to a form that can cause cases of paralytic polio, leading to an outbreak. This form is called a cVDPV.

questions.text: “NESTROFT” screening method as shown in the image below is performed for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• “NESTROFT” (Naked Eye Single Tube Red Cell Osmotic Fragility Test) is a useful screening tool in the diagnosis of beta thalassemia trait.
  • The principle of NESTROFT is based on the limit of hypotonicity which the red cell can withstand. 
  • In this procedure 2 ml of 0.36% buffered saline is taken in a test tube, 20ml of whole blood is added to it, and is allowed to stand at room temperature.
  • After 20 minutes reading is taken on a NESTROFT stand on which a thin black line is marked.
  • If the line is visible through the solution, the test is considered as negative and if line is not visible it is considered as positive.
  • Positive test is due to the reduced osmotic fragility of red cells.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child is receiving iron and folic acid supplements under the Weekly Iron and Folic Acid Supplementation (WIFS) Programme.  Which of the following is true about this program?

choices.text: It was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.
It is meant exclusively for adolescent school girls between 10-19 years of age.
It exclusively covers government schools in rural India.
It recommends that administration of 50 mg of elemental iron.

questions.solution:
Weekly Iron Folic acid Supplementation (WIFS) was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare is the true statement among the given options.

Salient features of Weekly Iron Folic acid Supplementation (WIFS):

i. Objective of Weekly Iron Folic acid Supplementation (WIFS): To reduce the prevalence and severity of anemia in the adolescent population (10-19 years).

ii. Target groups

  • School-going adolescent girls and boys in 6th to 12th class enrolled in government/government-aided/municipal schools
  • Out-of-school adolescent girls

iii. Intervention

  • Administration of supervised weekly iron-folic acid supplements of 60 mg elemental iron and 500 μg folic acid by using a fixed-day approach
  • Screening of target groups for moderate/severe anemia and referring these cases to an appropriate health facility
  • Biannual de-worming (albendazole 400 mg), six months apart, for the control of helminthic infestation
  • Information and counseling for improving dietary intake and for taking actions for prevention of intestinal worm infestation

The dose of iron–folic acid supplements is based on WIFS. Recently, a new scheme called Anemia Mukht Bharath was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, replacing all the other excisting schemes.

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.
