Note 1: Prophylaxis with iron should be withheld in case of acute illness (fever, diarrhea, pneumonia, etc.) and in a known case of thalassemia major/ history of repeated blood transfusion. In cases of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), IFA supplementation should be continued as per the SAM management protocol.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.

questions.text: An anxious mother brings her otherwise healthy neonate with the lesion show in image. What would you do?

choices.text: Low dose broad spectrum antibiotic prophylaxis

questions.solution:
Reassure the mother that it is benign as the image shows Epstein Pearls.

Epstein Pearls

  • Are nests of epithelial cells.
  • Appear as whitish/yellowish spots on the hard palate.
  • It may also occur over the tip of Prepuce at 6 o'clock position.
  • Usually, resolve in 3 months.

 No intervention is necessary as it resolves spontaneously and is a benign condition.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: You are a pathology resident who is looking at a slide, showing small round blue cells and Homer-Wright rosettes as shown below. The history you received from the pediatric surgery resident was that the specimen was resected from a 5-year-old child with ataxia. The tumor was present in the midline vermis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and slide are suggestive of Medulloblastoma. 

Medulloblastoma is an embryonal CNS tumor, occurring predominantly in the cerebellar vermis that causes ataxia, poor balance, and dysmetria. It may cause obstructive hydrocephalus and often metastasizes extraneurally.

Histopathology shows a tumor composed of small, round, blue cells and is characterized by Homer–Wright rosettes and an immunopositivity for synaptophysin. 

Standard treatment for medulloblastomas is surgical resection, with adjuvant craniospinal radiotherapy for those over 3 years of age and chemotherapy.
Prognosis is strongly influenced by surgical resection, the presence of CSF metastases at the time of diagnosis, and the expression of the c-erbB-2 (HER2/neu) oncogene.

Note: Small, round, blue-cell tumors are malignant neoplasms that have a characteristic appearance under the microscope. It consists of sheets of small round cells that stain blue on routine hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining. Examples are:

  • Medulloblastoma
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

A new study shows that children with medulloblastoma who were treated with radiotherapy had better intellectual outcomes when the radiation was delivered as proton beam therapy compared to traditional photon radiotherapy.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: Match the following congential malformation with its findings -
questions.solution:
Coffee bean sign is seen in sigmoid volvulus in plain erect xray.

Bird beak sign is seen in achalasia cardia in barium swallow.

Double bubble sign is seen in duodenal atresia in plain erect xray abdomen.

Multiple air fluid levels is seen in jejunal and ileal atresia in plain erect xray abdomen.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: You are evaluating JIA patients in a pediatric rheumatology clinic. As per the ILAR criteria, which of the following patients would you not include under JIA?

choices.text: A 18-year-old with RF negative Polyarthritis first diagnosed 3 years back

questions.solution:
Reactive arthritis is not a subtype of Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis(JIA) so you would not include this subset of patients under your evaluation.

ILAR (International League of Associations for Rheumatology) defines JIA as arthritis of one or more joints with onset below 16 years of age and persisting for at least 6 weeks.

The subtypes of Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA):-

  1. Oligoarthritis (4 or lesser joints) (Most common type)
  2. Polyarthritis (5 or more joints)
    1. RF Positive
    2. RF Negative
  3. Systemic JIA
  4. Psoriatic arthritis
  5. Enthesitis-related arthritis
  6. Undifferentiated
